definition: the seventy two martyrs of the Huanghuagang uprising of 23rd April 1911
pinyin: Huang2 hua1 gang1 qi1 shi2 er4 lie4 shi4

definition: surname Huang or Hwang
yellow/pornographic/to fall through
flower/blossom/CL:朵[duo3],支[zhi1],束[shu4],把[ba3],盆[pen2],簇[cu4]/fancy pattern/florid/to spend (money, time)/(coll.) lecherous/lustful

mound/policeman's beat
seven/7

ardent/intense/fierce/stern/upright/to give one's life for a noble cause/exploits/achievements

Huanghuagang uprising of 23rd April 1911 in Guangzhou, one a long series of unsuccessful uprisings of Sun Yat-sen's revolutionary party
Qiu Jin (1875-1907), famous female martyr of the anti-Qing revolution, the subject of several books and films
Huanghuagang (Chrysanthemum Hill) in Guangzhou, scene of disastrous uprising of 23rd April 1911
Zhang Tailei (1898-1927), founding member of Chinese communist party
martyr of the revolution

the Six Gentlemen Martyrs of the failed reform movement of 1898, executed in its aftermath, namely: Tan Sitong 譚嗣同|谭嗣同[Tan2 Si4 tong2], Lin Xu 林旭[Lin2 Xu4], Yang Shenxiu 楊深秀|杨深秀[Yang2 Shen1 xiu4], Liu Guangdi 劉光第|刘光第[Liu2 Guang1 di4], Kang Guangren 康廣仁|康广仁[Kang1 Guang3 ren2] and Yang Rui 楊銳|杨锐[Yang2 Rui4]
Huang Xing (1874-1916), revolutionary politician, close collaborator of Sun Yat-sen, prominent in the 1911 Xinhai Revolution 辛亥革命[Xin1 hai4 Ge2 ming4], murdered in Shanghai in 1916
martyr
Chen Tianhua (1875-1905), anti-Qing revolutionary from Hunan, drowned himself in Japan in 1905
to sacrifice oneself in a just cause/a victim of a disaster
Xinhai Revolution (1911), which ended the Qing Dynasty
Dr Sun Yat-sen (1866-1925), first president of the Republic of China and co-founder of the Guomintang 國民黨|国民党/same as 孫逸仙|孙逸仙
anti-imperialist movement of 30th May 1925, involving general strike esp. in Shanghai, Guangzhou, Hong Kong etc
Tan Sitong (1865-1898), Qing writer and politician, one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子 of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Cai E (1882-1916), originator of the National protection army of 1915
democratic revolution/bourgeois revolution (in Marx-Leninist theory, a prelude to the proletarian revolution)
